Introduction
1. The proposed Gaza Emergency Water Project (GEWP) is the fifthina series ofwater and sanitation projects supported by the Bank in the West Bank and Gaza (WBG) since the beginning o f the peace process in October 1993. It follows up on two recently approved projects: the Northern Gaza Emergency Sewage Treatment Project (NGEST, US$7.8 million, FY05) andthe Emergency Water Project (US$12.5 million, FY04). The former seeks to address critical sewage treatment and disposal problems in northern Gaza, while the latter seeks to address urgent water supply problems inthe southern area ofthe West Bank.
2. More importantly, though, the proposedproject (GEWP) seeks to consolidate and sustain the very successful achievements of the earlier Bank-supported Gaza Water and Sanitation Services Project (WSSP, TF026056, US$31 million, FY97),' which helped rehabilitate the networks and systems in Gaza, and improve water and wastewater services delivery through a private Management Contract (MC) Operator, as well as lay the foundation for the functional establishment of a Coastal Municipalities Water Utility (CMWU). While GEWP seeks to continue the initiatives of the WSSP, it has been developed in a significantly different and considerably more difficult context than its predecessor-a context of very deep political, social, economic, and institutional crisis which has enveloped WBG since September 2000-the beginning o f the second Palestinian Intifada.2 The proposed project has been shaped to a considerable extent by this crisis, one that only now seems to be beginning to abate.
The Crisis
3. The ensuing cycle o f violence and counter-violence on both sides took the lives of more than 3,100 Palestinians and about 980 Israelis. During the first two years of the crisis, Palestinian economic and social indicators fell dramatically: real gross national disposable income per capita declined by 29 percent between 1999 and 2003, while overall gross national income losses reached US$5.2 billion - equal to almost one year of pre-Intifada Palestinian national income. Physical damage was estimated at more than US$1.7 billion at replacement cost; capital stock declined by about 20 percent; total investment fell from about US$1.45 billion in 1999 to as little as US$500-550 million in2002. Per capita real income at the end of 2002 was only about half of what it had been three years earlier; the share of the population living in

7. An estimated US$900 million in overall infrastructure sector damage was inflicted on WBG between September 2000 and July 2003. The water and wastewater sector accounted for about US$140 million, or about 25 percent o f the total cost o f damage. Most o f the damage involved the breakage o f supply lines and the destruction o f water pumps and installations. As the crisis deepened, the P W A and municipalities were unable to collect fees from an increasingly impoverished citizenry. Supplies and spare parts depleted, and access to networks to undertake essential maintenance and repairs was curtailed by extensive Israeli military blockades, closures and curfews. As a result, many waterlines and sewers have gone un-repaired for lengthyperiods of time, and inmany municipalities the streets have been strewn with garbage. The challenge to public healthis obvious.
8. Inaddition, the crisis weakened the ability o f both PWA and the municipalities to meet their financial commitments to the Israeli Water Corporation(Mekhorot) for supplies provided- leading to a considerable build up o f arrears that the PA in the end had to settle with the Government o f Israel (GOI). Finally, with the crisis, the damage sustained to plant and equipment severely retarded PWA's and the municipalities' ability to implement their originally planned development and institutional reform programs. This was mainly due to the physical risks and movement restrictions on workers, contractors and consultants. The risks to life and limb and the cost and difficulties o f doing business reduced the willingness o f management contractors (agents) and potential investors to participate inthe management and development o f the sector, negatively impacting progress inpreparing new projects, including GEWP.
PWA Response
9. Recognizing the heightened threat to public health, the increased economic burden on households, and the financial and operational constraints on municipalities and villages, the PWA established the Emergency Water Operations Center (EWOC) in April 2002. This was done in close consultation with and strong support from the donor and NGO community. EWOC's mandate was largely limitedto the West Bank, partly because the problems there were more widespread and severe, and because o f the capacity already built up in Gaza by P W A and the municipalities under the WSSP and other donor supported projects. The purpose o f the EWOC was (and still is) to assist in responding to the growing humanitarian crisis through the prompt restoration o f basic water and sanitation services in the West Bank. EWOC has functioned very well to date. In the first six months o f operation, it disbursed about US$1.15 million for emergency repair works, managing to get the most severely damaged systems back up and running and delivering emergency supplies (including bottled water) and spares. An additional US$4.4 million has recently been made available to EWOC by donors for continuing emergency work. The focus is now on restocking o f supplies, helping to improve local preparedness, and moving beyond mere crisis management to help relieve social and economic hardship inthe most affected areas.5

Issues Remainingto beAddressedinGaza
14. Despite the progress achieved under WSSP, several issues remain to be addressed. For example: the drinking water supply in the Gaza Strip is still o f insufficient quality and is intermittent, with intemptions of supplies sometimes lasting for several days. Although about 98% o f households are connected to the drinking water supply network, households increasingly have to rely on water delivered by tankers or on bottled water, both delivered at a comparatively high cost. The salinity, and especially the nitrate content, of drinking water exceeds the World Health Organization (WHO) norms. Wastewater treatment is also most inadequate--existing ' treatment plants are overloaded, andtreated effluent and sludge are disposed o f inadequately. In addition, the already heavily overexploited groundwater is being contaminated by leakage from cesspools as well as by residues from fertilizers. About 140 million cubic meters (MCM) per year are being abstracted while the natural safe yield i s only about 60 M C M per year. Return flows are 50 M C M per year, leading to increasing seawater intrusion into the aquifer inthe order o f 30 M C M per year. Furthermore, as the population increases -mainly due to high natural growth - and the per capita water consumption rises, the demand for water will inevitably increase. This will place even more stress on the resource, supply anddelivery systems.
15. The main obstacle for improved service delivery is o f an institutional nature. Untilthe establishment o f CMWU, water and sanitation service delivery inthe Gaza Strip was fragmented between 25 municipal and village councils, whose managerial capacity i s weak andwhose tariffs still barely cover operation and maintenance costs. To make matters worse, municipalities frequentlydiverted water revenues to subsidize other municipal services. The water networks o f most municipalities were physically separate from one another, making it impossible to distribute to all municipalities urgently needed bulk water that would come either from future desalination or from imports.
16. In order to operate and to finance the expensive infrastructure needed to improve the supply and distribution system in Gaza, there are three prerequisites: (i) the establishment o f a

Additionally, the capacities o f newly established CMWU as well as that of the PWA need to be strengthened. Inparticular, CMWU, which will be the owner of the assets, would be responsible for setting and monitoring key objectives interms of service delivery, and hence needs to be fully operationalized. PWA, for its part, needs to be strengthened to enable it to focus effectively on regulating the sector, including environmental aspects such as groundwater quality, groundwater abstraction, and wastewater quality and discharge and selected economic aspects such as adherence to national water tariff guidelines.

LessonsLearnedfrom Similar OperationsandUtilizedinProjectDesign
25. Two sets o f lessons have been learned and incorporated in the project's design. Those specific to the successful M C under the WSSP andthe unsuccessful biddingprocess for an eight- year operating lease; and more general ones based on overall program experience.
26. Specific WSSP Lessons: The lessons specifically noted in the WSSP Implementation Completion Report (Report No. 26156) were as follows:
Borrower commitment and ownership:
Borrower's strong commitment for development o f the sector through the Project was a key factor that not only helped formulate the Project concept/design, but also facilitated its implementation at every successive stage. The strong ownership that the Project enjoyed i s amply demonstrated through the introduction o f the private Operator which ultimately caused a significant turn around inthe sector's overall performance through a "public-private partnership" that was based on mutual trust and confidence. This created an enabling environment for other donors to step-in, and provided much neededfinancing for the sector's further development. 27. Independent auditing necessary to build trust and certijj the annual performance incentivefee. In Gaza, where no regulatory capacity existed before the management contract went into effect, the contracting o f an independent reputable auditing firm proved to be essential inbuildingtrust between the public and private parties involved. 28. Management Contract
Providing higher degrees o f management responsibility to the Operator can expedite system improvements. As successful as the Operator was in meeting the requirements under its direct authority, local authorities were not always committed to supporting these improvements (e.g., conversion o f illegal connections). Despite the overall success o f the contract, the Operator was not able to consolidate the receivables o f all the municipality water departments. Thus, the initial financial position o f the newly created C M W U could be undermined by this unclear receivables position and implementation o f a clear actionplanto reduce them may be difficult. The new M C has paid particular attentionto reducing these receivables. Some o f the key features that enabled a successful implementation o f the M C include: (i)well-defined roles o f the P W A and the Operator (parties o f the contract); (ii)clear allocation o f risks between the PWA and the Operator; (iii) achievable performance targets; and (iv) a clear linkage between incentive fees andperformance.
29. Overall: The experience in Gaza suggests that MCs are likely to be the most effective form o fprivate participation under the following conditions:
The primary objective is to rapidly enhance the technical capacity and efficiency o f services. Government faces obstacles in committing to a long-term arrangement for private participation, or in attracting private sector investment that i s willing to bear commercial and/or political risks. Tariffs are too low to support a sustainable long-term arrangement for private participation. Government faces difficulties in securing agreements to allow the long-term involvement o f the private sector, due to an inappropriate/absence o f any regulatory framework. Putting in place a short-term M C allows the authorities to focus on adopting an appropriate strategy, creating a proper regulatory framework, adjust tariffs and subsidies; thus creating an environment that has the proper conditions for private sector participation and risk taking.
30. General Program Lessons: Important lessons have been learned from the recent emergency operations in WBG supported by the Bank. These relate to decentralization o f project preparation and implementation. The latter greatly facilitates implementation at a time
-10-  when central systems are unable to function effectively because of the security situation. In addition, the following has been learned:
The water and wastewater sector is one of the few in which dialogue and reasonable working relationships still persist among the professionals on the Palestinian and Israeli sides, and where consistent donor involvement has also facilitated the dialogue betweenthe Palestinian and Israeli parties. There appears to be a higher-level consensus that issues related to the management o f scarce water resources, and the health risks attached to a breakdown inwater and sanitation systems are too important to be left to the vagaries of the current crisis.
Consultative mechanisms such as the Joint Water Committee (JWC) bring together Israeli and Palestinian professionals (including the military) periodically to discuss sector issues. These mechanisms are working and have proved effective in sorting out many problems. SocialAspects
40. The social assessment findings (Annex 6) showed that most consumers were deeply concerned about inadequate water quality and poor regularity/predictability o f supply, and improvements in both would bring major public benefits. Given the high risk context o f the project, and the need to raise water revenues to viable levels, the main social development outcome should be to enhance confidence and trust (or least to take measures to prevent deterioration o f trust which would otherwise risk project outcomes). This should be done at two levels: to enhance trust between the individual consumer and the service provider, and to ensure public trust in the institutional arrangements for the sector. Subsidiary social development outcomes would be adequate safety nets for the very poor and improvement in customer behavior inrelation to water.
41. Implementation therefore requires attention not only to enhancing and improving customer satisfaction, but to measuring it objectively, communicating progress regularly, and establishing mechanisms o f consultation, handling o f complaints, and a transparent and accountable regulatory environment. Three actions are indicated, which have been included amongthe service responsibilities o fthe M C Operator :
a. Regularconsumer surveys are a useful tool to assess the extent o f consumer satisfaction and o f trust between consumers and service providers. Some o f the issues that could be covered by such surveys are consumer confidence in metering and billing; service time response to complaints and queries including billing; and the reliability o f supply.
b. Broad-based public informationcampaign should be conducted, including the media. The campaign should go well beyond explaining the need to save water, which has been the main or even unique activity in some awareness campaigns in other countries. The
-14-  campaign should explain the role o f the private sector Operator; the role given to consumers inmonitoringthe Operator through regular surveys, consumer committees and their board representative; special measures to be introduced to protect the needy; the functioning of the complaints process; the need to increase tariffs in order to provide improved services, in particular improved water quality through desalination and piped sewerage; indicating what the project can and cannot do, at least in the short term, pendingmajor capital investments.
c. Targeted Support Payments to the Poor: Currently, municipalities exempt some consumers from paying their water bills or forgive the accumulated arrears on water bills, presumably on the basis of social need. However, the current practice may not be well targeted to the poor, since these exemptions are apparently often granted as favors to relatives and friends. The newly approved by-lawsfor the CMWU do not allow for such mechanism to continue. The Operator i s askedto proposea more targeted system.
42. A possible fourth action would be the formation of consumer committees in each municipality or group of municipalities. These committees could serve as an interface between the utility and the consumers, holding public meetings, providing feedback to the Operator and CMWU on consumer priorities and concerns, and having the right to accede to information from the Operator, thus increasingtransparency.

The proposed project has three main components:

This component includes support for the employment o f a Private Sector Operator under a MC, competitively bid under Bank procurement guidelines. In general, the Operator will ensure the functional establishment o f the C M W U in Gaza, improved management o f the water and wastewater systems, as well as an improvement in the operation and quality o f water and wastewater services inGaza. For the provision o f these services, the Operator will be paid a fixed management fee o f US$6.2 million and a performance-based incentive fee with a ceiling o f US$2.4 million.
The Management Fee: The management fixed fee will be paid to the Operator to provide for mobilization and operating costs during the period o f the contract and finance the necessary staff to implementthe service improvement program.
The Incentive Fee: The incentive fee will depend on the achievement o f the performance targets specified inthe MC. EnvironmentalAssessment
The proposed project would contribute to improving the environment through better management of existing water and sanitation facilities, through increased expenditure on essential operations and maintenance, and through a capital investment program to expand and improve water and sanitation infrastructure. Currently there are no known project proposals whose implementation would require land acquisition or result in involuntary resettlement. No known archaeological or historical sites would be affected by rehabilitation sub-projects, nor does the operating investment component of the project raise any international water issues. The capital investment activities to be supported comprise rehabilitation, upgrading and extension of pipedwater supply and sewerageservices inurbanareas andwater supply improvements inrural, areas. The project does not include new wastewater treatment facilities. The project does not include any component with major environmental impact and will result in significant improvement inenvironmental quality through improvedwater and sanitation services.
Environmental impact will be mitigated by improved operations and maintenance o f water and sewerage services, which will improve the efficiency o f water use and reduce the need for tapping new resources. Substantial past and future investments by other donors have provided adequate collection systemsto accommodate increasedwastewater discharges resultingfrom this project. Management will be improved by the Operator but treatment capacity, which is inadequate, will not be directly increasedas a result of this project. However there are plans to build several wastewater treatment plants (funded by donors) to treat the collected sewage and reuse the treated effluent.
The proposed project has been classified under the environmental category "B" in accordance withthe World Bank's Operational Policy 4.01 on Environmental Assessments. Accordingly, an Environmental Impact Assessment and Environmental Mitigation and Management Plan has beenpreparedas part of Project preparation.
Keyfindings on EnvironmentalIssues
An Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) and Environmental Management Plan (EMP) were completed in March 2001 and remain germane to the planned project. They were assessed during appraisal and are determinedto remain fully relevant. The complete text of the EIA and EMP is on file with the World Bank Infoshop and available to the public via internet, and Bank Staff via intranet (through the "Project Portal") and from the Task Team.
Under the EIA, the environmental resourcesthat are of particular interest to the implementation of the EMP were surveyed. Additionally, sample site-specific projects from five municipalities were selected to assist in describing and assessing existing conditions, as well as summarizing potential impacts.
Multiple issues were studied to assess the environmental impacts, including: drilling and/or rehabilitating wells, disinfecting potable water, operating desalination plants, establishing new water and wastewater networks, rehabilitating existing water and wastewater networks, constructing cesspits for wastewater disposal, improving wastewater treatment plants,
-51-  rehabilitating wastewater pumping stations, and reusing treated wastewater for agriculture and infiltration. The EIA/EMP also addresses the effects of general construction activities and new tariffstructures.
The EMP details potential impacts and proposes mitigation measures. Responsibility for execution, mitigation monitoring measures and methods, and monitoring and enforcement i s clearly spelled out betweenthe PMU and operating consultant.
In order to monitor the project's compliance with the EMP and coordinate the environmental training program, the Project Management Unit (PMU) will include environmental specialists. The PMU's environment staff will be augmented, as necessary, by part time environmental advisors and consultants, bothlocaland international.
The environmental capacity building and training program will focuses on the preparation and use of the appraisal/mitigation form, use o f environmental guidelines, and implementation o f the EMP. Safety measures, proper waste disposal, and cleaning measures during construction are also addressed.
It is estimated that the implementation of the EMP will cost US$326,000, includingthe cost of employing the environmental expert, capacity building and training programs, periodic environmental assessment for water and wastewater projects, and a contingency budget for any archaeological survey necessitatedby an unexpected chance find.
Social Development Issues and Implementation Strategy
Keyfindings on SocialIssues
The social assessment findings showed that most consumers were deeply concerned about inadequatewater quality and poor regularity/predictability of supply, and improvements in both would bring major public benefits. There is strong support for individual metering and the eliminationof free riders. Institutionally there is support for the setting up o f a CWU to improve management, but also concern to ensure institutionalaccountability, particularly inthe context of deep mistrust inthe overall regional political economy o f water resource allocation and limited public information. There is support for the involvement of other institutions (Environment, Health) on quality control, and for consumer representation on the governing board.
On tariffs, consumers would be willing to pay additional amounts for improved quality, but the actual ability to do so i s rather limited (especially with the changes in the last 12 months). It would also have to take into account the poverty situation. Gaza's historic poverty rates have been higher than inthe West Bank and over 2/3 o f new poverty (since October 2000) is located there, with the likelihood that recovery will be slow and difficult. A major coping strategy o f the poor has been to defer payment of utility bills (water, electricity, telephone) although only the poorest of families get into serious arrears. Social safety nets to protect the most vulnerable are porous and have limited coverage. The implication o f all this i s that tariff increases should be accompanied by effective dissemination o f information, cultivation of customer relations, monitoring of impacts on the poor and very poor and special provisions (universally supported) for the very poor.
-52-  Social Development Outcome
Given the high risk context o f the project, and the need to raise water revenues to viable levels, the main social development outcome should be to enhance confidence andtrust (or least to take measures to prevent deterioration o f trust which would otherwise risk project outcomes). This should be done at two levels: to enhance trust between the individual consumer and the service provider, and to ensure public trust in the institutional arrangements for the (sub) sector. Subsidiary social development outcomes would be adequate safety nets for the very poor and improvement incustomer behavior inrelation to water.
Implementation Strategyfor SocialDevelopment Outcomes
Trust is a deeper andmore durable concept than customer satisfaction, and requires attention not only to enhance and improve customer satisfaction, but to measure it objectively, communicate progress regularly, as well as establish mechanisms o f consultation, handlingo f complaints, and a transparent and accountable regulatory environment. The lead agencies for the various sub- components remain to be determined among the CMWU, PWA, the Operator and the social services administration.
Regular ConsumerSurveys
Consumer surveys are a useful tool to assess the extent o f consumer satisfaction and o f trust between consumers and service providers. Some o f the issues that could be covered by such surveys are consumer confidence in metering and billing; service time response to complaints andqueries including billing; and the reliability o f supply. However, inorder to provide reliable and incontestable results, such surveys need to be accurate and have to be conducted by highly qualified, professional firms using a representative sample o f sufficient size and a transparent methodology. Even in developed countries, the reliability o f the results o f such surveys i s sometimes challenged. In WBG, where capacity in conducting such surveys in an accurate and reliable manner is apparently limited, these concerns are more serious. Therefore, it is inappropriate to use beneficiary-derived indicators as part o f the performance indicators that determine the bonus payment to the private Operator; however, consumer surveys should be conducted in order to provide information to help ensure project outcomes. Recent experience concerning Bank work on citizen participatory monitoring o f public services as well as technical assistancecould be made available to CMWU, which would contract out such surveys.
Recommendation: CMWU should contract services of local consultants to conduct a pilot consumer surveys, to be followed by regular such surveys.
Public I nformation Campaign
It is important to increase the public confidence inthe institutional structure. Transparency is an essential prerequisite for such confidence.
Recommendation:A broad-based public information campaign should be conducted, including the media. The campaign should go well beyond explaining the need to save water, which has been the main or even unique activity in some awareness campaigns in other countries. The campaign should explain the role o f the private sector Operator; the role given to consumers in
-53-  monitoring the Operator through regular surveys, consumer committees and their board representative; special measures to be introduced to protect the needy; the functioning o f the complaints process; the need to increase tariffs in order to provide improved services, in particular improved water quality through desalination and piped sewerage; indicating what the project can and cannot do, at least in the short term, pending major capital investments. The campaign would place particular emphasis on the need to identify illegal connections to prevent free rider behavior. Most illegal connections have been identified and many have been regularized, but some illegal connections remain, including a large share o f connections used by industries. CMWU could implement the public information campaign, with a significant input from local consultants. Parts o fthe campaign could be undertaken by the Operator.
TargetedSupport Payments to the Poor
Currently, municipalities exempt some consumers from paying their water bills or forgive the accumulated arrears on water bills, presumably on the basis of social need. However, the current practice may not be adequately targeting the poor, since these exemptions are apparently often granted as favors to relatives and friends. The present system should be discontinued once the C M W U is functionally established under the new project and replaced with a more targeted system.
However, it is not yet clear what form o f targeted support payments should and could be introduced under the project. There is a need to identify poor water users who would find it difficult to pay their water bills, to monitor the impacts o f tariff reforms on very poor households and on poor users o f singly-metered sources, and to monitor the implementation o f targeted financial support. The utility may not be best placed to perform these functions. The existing social services system, including the Ministry o f Social Affairs, UNRWA and the NGO network which plays an important part in social services delivery and community representatives, are better placed to identify such households, deliver and monitor targeted support payments. One option i s to levy a small surcharge on water bills to fund targeted financial support for poor households. The eligibility criteria should be defined by the social services. The revenues could be channeled into a special fund that would be controlled by both the C M W U and the social services administration, and which would be subject to transparent rules to be communicated to all water users through the media and other channels. Another option would be to identify grant fundingfrom a donor, possibly underan on-going project. The funding requirements would be in the order o f US$ 0.3 million per year, if the poorest 10 % o f users were targeted and half their water billwould be paid from the fund.
Recommendation: Identify an appropriate entity to implement targeted support payments as well as the necessary funding.
Consumer Committeesand ConsumerRepresentative on the CMWU
The current membership o f the C M W U board includes mayors as well as a university professor and a representative o fthe business community. This arrangement does not provide for sufficient representation o fwater users.
-54-  Recommendation:It is suggestedthat consumer committees are formed ineach municipality or group o f municipalities. These committees could serve as an interfacebetween the utility and the consumers, holding public meetings, providing feedback to the Operator and C M W U on consumer priorities and concerns, and having the right to accede to information from the Operator, thus increasing transparency. Members o f the consumer committees could be nominated by the municipalities and NGOs. Members would receive a small compensation closely related to their efforts, i.e. linked to the number o f community meeting organized. Membership would however be a part-time and volunteer function. It would be appropriate to phase the formation o fthese consumer committees with the implementationo f works.
Consumer committees could help in setting up rules for eligibility o f targeted support payments to the poor, in public awareness campaigns, in drafting the Terms of Reference, supervising or perhaps carrying out consumer surveys as well as assisting vulnerable groups, such as poor living on illegal land who are not entitled to individual water connections. Concerning the latter group, the existing procedures allow them to receive individual water connections, if the Ministryo fHousingconfirms that the owners o fthe landwould not claim user rights onthe land. Consumer committees could help insettling such issues.
Furthermore, a consumer representative could be included on the board o f the CMWU. Given that there apparently are no established consumer groups inthe Gaza Strip, it may be difficult to identify a suitable candidate. One possibility would be to include a representative from an NGO that works with refugees (who are among the poorest and least well served) and/or inthe area o f health (because o f the impact o f intermittent supply and low water quality on health). The representative could be a woman, since all other board members are likely to be men and because women are more aware o f the consequences o f intermittent supply and low water quality.

In the absence of fully consolidated set of audited financial statements for the municipalities making up the CMWU, the financial analysis was carried out based solely on pro-forma consolidated limited purpose income statements prepared by PWA with data collected from all municipalities. Based on the pro-forma consolidated limitedpurpose income statements prepared by PWA, the municipalities are incurring net losses mainly due to their inability to collect the revenue for billed water sales and sewage fees. At present, maintenance expenditures have been kept to a minimum, given the inability of the municipalities to financially cope with the costs of appropriately maintainingtheir water andwastewater systems.
The analysis uses a cost-benefit structure, estimating the future financial performance o f the municipalities with or without the project, as well as the net present value in financial terms for the duration of the management contract. A longer-term forecast of the management contract's impact is shown in Table 3, followed by key assumptions inTable 4. This base scenario forecast has been prepared mainly to foresee the possible financial benefits if the level of service is maintained at the same levels as the ones targeted at the end of the management contract for an additional 4 years, in case the option to extend the management contract is undertaken. As it i s shown, the NPV ofthe operating cashflow for this period is positive at NIS 16.3 million (US$3.7 million).
The management contract financed by the project will generate financial benefits to the water andwastewater sector inGazamainlythrough an increaseinthe revenue collectionratio, as well as through a decrease inunaccounted-for water, while increasing the maintenance expenses so as to ensure an appropriate level o fmaintenanceto the network.
Other benefits range from the provision of additional water supply capacity to better satisfy the targeted population, to securing water supply and protecting water quality at a lower cost. The project will allow households to consume a larger volume o f water than any other alternative, which will increase their welfare (the consumer surplus) and the revenues for the utility. The institutional component o fthe project will provide differentbenefits; among them it will improve the finances of the water utility, its management, and will result in reduced operating costs. doc.repnme: West Bank and Gaza - Emergency Water Project
doc.abstracts: The Gaza Emergency Water Project aims to improve the provision of adequate water and wastewater services in Gaza, and functionally establish the Coastal Municipalities Water Utility (CMWU) as an autonomous well-run modem utility. In addition, the project has a secondary objective to strengthen the Palestinian Water Authority's (PWA) capacity to assume sector regulatory functions. The proposed project will achieve the outlined objectives through: a) funding a 3-year performance-based management contract to functionally establish the CMWU, as well as to improve the operation and quality of water and wastewater services in Gaza. b) providing funds to purchase materials, supplies and equipment that are required to rehabilitate water and wastewater infrastructure and enhance the efficient operation, maintenance and administration of water and wastewater systems in the service area. c) providing technical assistance and capacity building support to the PWA and the CMWU, as well as the employment of an independent auditor to audit the management contract outputs.
